NY POP ART

UT has long partnered with pop art pioneers, including Andy Warhol, Keith Haring, and Jean-Michel Basquiat. These legendary artists have left behind various works that make art more accessible and enjoyable for people. Experience the joy of wearing pop art that is loved across generations.

Jean-Michel Basquiat
An icon of New York in the 1980s, Jean-Michel Basquiat became renowned during his short career for works inspired by his early street art and a distinctive iconography often connected to art history. His paintings, drawings, and prints drew on a diverse range of sources, from African, Aztec, and Greek cultures to Americana in the form of jazz, baseball, and social and political events.

© Estate of Jean-Michel Basquiat. Licensed by Artestar, New York.

UT has long partnered with pop art pioneers, including Andy Warhol, Keith Haring, and Jean-Michel Basquiat. These legendary artists have left behind various works that make art more accessible and enjoyable for people. Experience the joy of wearing pop art that is loved across generations.

Keith Haring
A key figure in New York’s East Village scene in the late 1970s and 80s, American artist Keith Haring’s artwork populated not only art galleries, but also the city’s subways, streets, and sidewalks. His work often combined an iconographic vocabulary, including hearts, flying saucers, winged figures, and a crawling “radiant baby,” with abstract marks and patterning.

© Keith Haring Foundation. Licensed by Artestar, New York.

Andy Warhol
As the preeminent American artist of the 20th century, Andy Warhol challenged the world to see art differently. Since its founding in 1987, in accordance with Andy Warhol’s will, The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts has established itself among the leading funders of contemporary art in the United States. Proceeds the Foundation receives from licensing projects such as this contribute to the Foundation’s endowment from which these grants are distributed.

Andy Warhol
As the preeminent American artist of the 20th century, Andy Warhol challenged the world to see art differently. Since its founding in 1987, in accordance with Andy Warhol’s will, The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts has established itself among the leading funders of contemporary art in the United States. Proceeds the Foundation receives from licensing projects such as this contribute to the Foundation’s endowment from which these grants are distributed.

items.longDescription:
Disney in Blue

BUAISOU, an indigo dyer and farmer collective known for blending tradition with modern craftsmanship, has garnered worldwide attention. Inspired by the rich hues of natural indigo, UNIQLO has launched an exclusive collection featuring Mickey Mouse and his friends as its motifs. Enjoy this beautiful lineup of blues crafted from the finest indigo. Note: The products use synthetic dyes inspired by natural indigo.

BUAISOU
Founded in 2015 and based in Kamiita Town, Tokushima Prefecture, BUAISOU manages the entire indigo dyeing process—from cultivating indigo and producing the dye material, "sukumo," to crafting the final products— traditionally carried out by separate artisans. In addition to creating original indigo-dyed items and collaborating with others, they also participate in exhibitions and workshops both in Japan and abroad,sharing the beauty of natural indigo through various methods.

©Disney

Doraemon meets the Louvre

Doraemon, Japan’s popular character created by Fujiko・F・Fujio, and his friends visits the Louvre, enjoying its art and even stepping into the world of its masterpieces. Enjoy this unique UT collection, where you can journey with Doraemon and his friends through the timeless and radiant world of art that continues to shine across space and time.

items.longDescription:
Disney in Blue

BUAISOU, an indigo dyer and farmer collective known for blending tradition with modern craftsmanship, has garnered worldwide attention. Inspired by the rich hues of natural indigo, UNIQLO has launched an exclusive collection featuring Mickey Mouse and his friends as its motifs. Enjoy this beautiful lineup of blues crafted from the finest indigo. Note: The products use synthetic dyes inspired by natural indigo.

BUAISOU
Founded in 2015 and based in Kamiita Town, Tokushima Prefecture, BUAISOU manages the entire indigo dyeing process—from cultivating indigo and producing the dye material, "sukumo," to crafting the final products— traditionally carried out by separate artisans. In addition to creating original indigo-dyed items and collaborating with others, they also participate in exhibitions and workshops both in Japan and abroad,sharing the beauty of natural indigo through various methods.

©Disney

Doraemon meets the Louvre
